Introduction

Medical devices play a key role in healthcare, vital for diagnosis, therapy, monitoring, rehabilitation and care. Effective management of this important resource is required to satisfy high quality patient care, clinical and financial governance, including minimising risks of adverse events. Unless medical devices are managed proactively, the same types of adverse incidents happen repeatedly. Good medical device management will greatly assist in reducing their potential for harm.
The policy applies to all staff, services and divisions who are involved with the purchase, supply, maintenance, decontamination and use of medical equipment.

data.text: Scope

The purpose of this document is to outline a systematic approach to the acquisition, training, deployment, maintenance (preventive maintenance and performance assurance), repair and disposal of medical devices.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Health and Safety Management group is responsible for receiving reports from the Medical Devices Group and escalation.
Medical Devices Group is responsible for the discussion and escalation of issues with medical devices.
Chief Executive

The Chief Executive as the Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Senior Director of Estates and Facilities

The Senior Director of Estates and Facilities has the delegated responsibility to ensure full implementation of this policy. They will oversee the planning of the replacement programme for the Trust's medical equipment and the procurement plan for new equipment into the Trust.
Head of MEMS
The Head of MEMS is responsible for:
Overseeing Medical Device Contracts Management,
The delivery of the Medical Equipment Management Services (MEMS)
Ensuring that the Trust's centralised equipment asset inventory is developed and maintained, in line with entry of appropriate medical equipment onto the capital asset register.

Information on all items of reusable medical equipment shall be collected in the form of an equipment inventory which will identify the type of equipment, its users, owners, and those who are responsible for revenue costs (see below). This information will be used for several management purposes, for example to allow the speedy recovery of equipment following receipt of hazard warnings and to permit meaningful planning of replacement of the Trust's medical equipment.
The Risk and Compliance Team

The members of the Risk and Compliance Team are the nominated liaison officers for reporting device related adverse events to the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA). The Risk and Compliance Team are also registered with the Central Alerting System (CAS) and action alerts accordingly.
The Procurement Department and MEMS

All medical equipment shall be procured by the Procurement Department taking into account the preferred choice for standard types of equipment and consumables as agreed by any user/ group and in accordance with the Trust's:

Standing Financial Instructions. The Purchasing department will ensure compliance with appropriate documentation procedures are completed; that equipment is appropriately CE marked (a manufacturer's claim that the product meets European directives).
Purchases of Medical Devices are authorised through MEMS via PAQ for inclusion on the equipment inventory.

MEMS will assess information available with particular concern for safety, re- usability and maintainability and make recommendations about proposed purchases (which should include checking suitability of ex-demonstration/nearly new equipment).
The Manufacturer/Supplier

The Medical Devices Regulations states that the manufacturer or supplier of a medical device is responsible for supplying appropriate instructions including information needed to use the device safely, (taking account of the training and knowledge of potential users).
Medical Device Safety Officer (MDSO) Is responsible for:
Being an active member of the National Medical Devices Safety Network;
Improving reporting of and learning from medical devices incidents.
Reviewing all medical devices incident reports to ensure data quality for local and national learning, and where necessary investigate and get additional information from reporters.
Respond to requests for more information from the Patient Safety Domain in
NHS England and the MHRA about medical device incident reports.
Act as an additional senior point of contact for manufacturers and support local actions on Field Safety Notices.
Medical Equipment Training Co-ordinator Is responsible for:
Assisting managers and users, to identify medical equipment training needs.
Identifying training requirements with new equipment and facilitating user training.
Facilitating training delivery by an appointed training officer.
Divisional Medical Directors

The Divisional Medical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff complies with the contents of the document. They are also responsible for approving any relevant bids for new equipment.
Deputy Directors of Operations

The Deputy Directors of Operations are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
It is for them to:
Identify Divisional Lead(s) for equipment control (Practice Education Facilitators)
They will ensure systems are in place to identify, evaluate, and select new equipment required for the Division
Identify with MEMS annual plans for a rolling programme of replacement equipment to maintain service provision.
Inform MEMS to ensure that all new equipment is entered onto the capital asset register and the equipment asset inventory.

The replacement of equipment is necessarily associated with capital bids and the ‘ownership' of equipment with capital charges. Equipment either hired of borrowed from a third party that is subsequently damaged through misuse or neglect or loss will be the responsibility of the directorate who hired or borrowed it.
Practice Education Facilitators (PEF)

The PEF is responsible for ensuring that ward / departmental managers provide supervision for all equipment, ensuring that users deploy, manage, transfer, maintain and use medical devices safely in line with relevant policies, procedures, training and instructions, legislation and guidance. The ward / departmental managers can identify individuals within the area to assist with this process.
Departmental Equipment Controller (DEC)
Where areas have a DEC, the DEC is responsible at the Ward / Department level for:
All medical equipment including borrowed or hired by a third party.
Ensuring that equipment is adequately decontaminated before it is serviced and for providing documentation to confirm this
All medical equipment users

All health care professionals are accountable for ensuring they deploy, manage, transfer, maintain and use medical equipment safely in line with relevant policies, procedures, training and instructions, legislation and guidance. Relevant legislation includes Health and safety at Work Act 1974, the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1992 and Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations 1992. All staff have a responsibility to report and withdraw damaged medical equipment for repair. If an untoward incident occurs as a result of lack of knowledge or wilful misuse of equipment, following the introductory period of this policy, then remedial training and possibly disciplinary action shall be taken in accordance with the conduct and capability policy.
All users should check the Service label on medical devices is within date and withdraw from use and report wherever possible.
Risk Management Responsibilities

The Trust owns and accepts responsibility in compliance with this policy and associated procedures for all medical equipment that has been properly brought into the Trust. Items that are “newly delivered” i.e. are new to the Trust or have been borrowed, loaned or are on demonstration must be used in accordance with this policy.
Medical equipment maintenance is organised via:
MEMS
The manufacturer
A third party and in some cases by identified Departments (Pathology and Imaging).
Details of all medical equipment owned by the Trust will be held on a central inventory (Medusa - equipment management software system).

MEMS will ensure access to Medusa for DEC(s) which will contain details of their equipment and other equipment related information to assist users in the safe and correct use of their equipment. Ward or department managers and DEC's are responsible for keeping instruction manuals and any other relevant documentation in a readily accessible place for staff use. User manuals are also accessible via the MEMS intranet page.
Acquisition and acceptance into use: (loan/ lease or rental/long
term etc.)
MEMS are the Trust's lead in relation to managing the acquisition and acceptance of all reusable medical devices, this involves:

Verifying that the agreed requirement takes account of the needs and preferences of all interested parties, including those involved in the commissioning, use, maintenance, decontamination and decommissioning of medical equipment.

Standardisation - The Trust will seek to reduce the number of different models and types of medical equipment in use in the Trust, as recommended by the National Audit Office (HC475, ‘The Management of Medical Equipment in NHS Acute Trusts in England') and MHRA - Managing Medical Devices 2021

Verifying that all new equipment has been checked and meets both the tendered specification and legal safety requirements through review of the PAQ and input from relevant specialist advisors when appropriate (e.g. Radiation Protection Advisor, Sterile Services Department)

Verifying that loan or rental equipment has been checked and meets the legal safety requirements: in all cases it must be clear at the outset whose responsibility it will be should any problems arise. MEMS should be consulted before any device loan is arranged
Managing the formal commissioning process
Ensuring appropriate training is available for users and MEMS technicians
Maintenance and repair
All staff must ensure that equipment is checked, in date and safe to use, as indicated in the manufacturer's instruction or other guidance provided by the Trust, and that the details are recorded.

Any internal or external technical department that undertakes maintenance and repair on medical equipment must have their service registered to ISO 9001 or an equivalent auditable quality management system.
Maintenance falls into the following categories:
User checks (user care and maintenance)
Scheduled servicing/calibration (planned maintenance)
Unscheduled maintenance (reactive repair)
User checks

Routine maintenance by the user should ensure that the device continues to function correctly. It entails regular inspection and care, as recommended in the manufacturer's user information or in local procedures, these will include:
Checking that it is working correctly before use
Regular cleaning
Checking the equipment has been serviced
Specific checks as recommended
Noting when it has stopped working properly or when obvious damage has occurred, then discontinuing use and contacting MEMS
Safe and secure storage
Scheduled/unscheduled servicing/calibration

The frequency and level of planned preventive maintenance is risk assessed by the MEMS technicians and historic data, considering the manufacturer's maintenance recommendations for the device, the risk category and impact on service delivery from failure.
A label on the device will inform users of the next service date.
When a medical device requires service or repair, users must report it immediately to MEMS via telephone or e-mail to the MEMS Helpdesk or to a MEMS Technician while on site.

A maximum of three attempts will be made in order to service the equipment. If unsuccessful in gaining access to the device and the service remains outstanding, the owner of the equipment will be informed. Any equipment that has its schedule rolled forward following unavailability will be raised as a Datix incident.
Decontamination
Staff must ensure that equipment is decontaminated before being returned for service or maintenance and the appropriate certificate of contamination status completed:
Using the correct decontamination processes is essential to prevent the spread of infections. By preference, single use devices and accessories should be used wherever practicable.
Single use devices must not be re-used under any circumstances.

Single patient devices must not be used on different service users. Staff should be aware that reusable medical equipment sometimes have accessories, which fall into the category of single patient devices. These should always be replaced between service users.
Reusable medical equipment should be cleaned, disinfected or sterilised as appropriate and in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
It is the responsibility of the user to ensure that medical equipment is decontaminated after use and left in an operational state.
The decontamination process should follow the manufacturer's instructions and or the guidance, policies and procedures provided by Infection Prevention
The Trust has a definitive and comprehensive Infection Control Policy which includes the requirements for decontamination of medical equipment
Decommissioning and disposal
Decommissioning aims to make devices safe and unusable, while minimising damage to the environment. Any device deemed unsafe for use should be decommissioned.
MEMS will be notified of medical equipment requiring decommissioning. The decommissioning process ensures that equipment is prepared for re-marketing or rendered safe and unusable.
MEMS will ensure all patient identifiable information is removed in the decommissioning process.
Upon re-marketing used equipment, appropriate disclaimer contracts should be completed between MEMS and the remarketing organisation.
Documentation relating to maintenance, service and training requirements with service history, should be supplied with the equipment to the re-marketing organisation.
The Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE) Regulations

impose duties on ‘producers', i.e., manufacturers and suppliers to provide details on disposal. Waste products requiring specialised disposal should be identified and managed correctly In line with World Health Organization guidelines (2000), the Trust does not donate equipment that is obsolete or deemed unfit for use.
Replacement

MEMS have knowledge of the equipment inventory, and the performance of specific items of equipment, and will develop a Medical Equipment Replacement Programme (MERP). This programme is submitted annually by MEMS to the Investment Group for review.
Clock synchronisation

Standardisation of the setting of medical equipment clocks within the Trust is intended to avoid confusion from the point of view of staff and legal authorities who might use medical equipment records, minimise the time spent making adjustment, and minimise the risk to patients from non-standard clock setting on medical equipment.
For the purpose of this policy Medical devices with displayed clocks are divided into two categories.
Reliable time: Connected to a network and updated automatically via the network
Unreliable Time: Any other device that is unable to automatically update its time.
Devices with Reliable time will be identified with a label indicating so.
Figure 1 Reliable time label
Note: Devices not displaying a reliable time sticker will not be routinely adjusted for seasonal clock shift.
Medical equipment library (MEL)
The MEL is a central store providing commonly used medical devices to support the existing ward equipment during high demand.
The MEL supplies decontaminated and maintained equipment required only on a short term basis and this must be returned after each patient use.
The MEL provides equipment delivery and collection services; the operating process is included in Appendix
Loaned equipment to patients and carers

When equipment is loaned to a patient or carer, the manager must ensure that there are adequate facilities for its safe use and that any necessary instruction and training have been provided. A record must be kept of these checks.
Patients own equipment

Where possible patients own equipment will be swapped out with Trust equipment for the duration of their stay to ensure clinical training, in the event this is not possible the Medical Equipment Training Co-ordinator is to be contacted to support with arranging appropriate clinical training for the device.
Adverse incidents and central alert system

In the event of an incident occurring which involves a piece of medical equipment, the MHRA must be informed by the MDSO. All Hazard and Safety Notices sent from the MHRA are managed centrally by the Governance, Risk and Compliance.

MEMS will analyse safety and hazard notices, from the MHRA or independent manufacturer, relevant to the medical equipment maintained by themselves and advise ward and department managers of any technical action that needs to be undertaken.

MEMS will receive manufacturer's safety or modification instructions and ensure that they are implemented with appropriate urgency for any items of equipment for which they are responsible. No modification to any item of medical equipment will be permitted unless it has been approved
by the manufacturer or else has been thoroughly reviewed by senior technical staff and evaluated for any risk associated with the modification.
Software

The MHRA states that standalone software for diagnosis including apps that are designed to diagnose are classified as medical devices. All software including medical devices is subject to Digital Services review and approval before use.
Training requirements
User training:
Users have professional accountability and a legal duty to ensure that their own knowledge and skills are appropriate and remain up to date.
Users must have evidence of the appropriate knowledge and skills in order to use medical equipment safely.

A Job Role Matrix (JRM) (Appendix ) will be completed by each speciality with the support of the METC and held locally. Competency forms will be provided with the Job Role Matrix or may be obtained from the METC.
The Job Role Matrix will identify the following:
Equipment that the user is authorised to use in that area.
Risk level of equipment (table 1)
Frequency of training and review period.

Competency forms contain details of the subject matter including the level of training, the users name and professional details. Competency forms require self- verification or assessor sign-off. Training completed on equipment deemed as high risk will require verification by the Dept / clinical service manager or PEF. Training records will be held by the user and LMS will be populated.
Training compliance is obtained and monitored by each Clinical Directorate and reported to the risk and compliance group.
It is through this process that training compliance is monitored. Where non- compliance is identified, staff will be requested to complete the necessary training as soon as possible.
New equipment

The PEF/Technologist/User should review the training needs when a new item of equipment is delivered. If the item is unfamiliar to any member of staff then training must be provided and LMS updated on completion. Until such time as the training has been completed, the member of staff must use the equipment under supervision only. All staff must read the instruction manuals and that these are stored in a place that is familiar and accessible to all staff at all times.
New starters

All new staff employed by the Trust will undertake competency assessment for equipment used, appropriate to their role. In cases where the medical devices and equipment are an integral part of professional training it will be assumed that professional competence has been achieved in order for the practitioner to gain registration status e.g., Radiographer, Surgical Practitioner, provided that induction and orientation has been undertaken with regards to the models of equipment used in the department and a record maintained.
Cascade Training – Cascade or train-the-trainer systems involve training a small group or individual who then disseminate to users.

Refresher Training – Following the user's initial training, the frequency of the refresher training identified in the JRM may be adjusted depending on the extent that the user operates the device. A user that operates equipment on a regular basis may not need further training at the time of review and this will be recorded on the LMS.
Training facilitated by the METC – The METC will often organise training events, registers of attendees will be taken and training events entered into LMS by MEMS.
Temporary staff

Temporary staff must be deemed competent to use the medical devices that may be used in their course of work. If competence cannot be proved, the temporary member of staff must be supervised or not permitted to use the medical device.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Management Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and Safety Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 2: Medical equipment library (MEL) requesting and returning medical devices

Requesting Equipment – Equipment can be requested by contacting the Medical Equipment Library (MEL) during normal working hours, alternatively for out of hours the Portering Service will be able to assist.
The MEL operates from Monday – Friday (excluding Bank Holidays) 08:00hrs – 16:00hrs and can be contacted via the MEMS Helpdesk on ext. 2021.
Or via email: MEMSHelpdesk.mse@nhs.net
In the event that the MEMS Helpdesk are unable to take your call during normal working hours, please leave a voice message, ensuring the following information is provided:
Type of Equipment
Delivery Location
Patient Name

The MEL holds a stock of commonly used medical devices such as Infusion Pumps, Syringe Pumps, Feed Pumps, Pressure Relieving Equipment and more; for further details of all equipment available from the MEL please refer to the Trust Intranet and search MEL, here you will find details of all the equipment and consumables available.

Equipment Delivery – Whilst every effort is made to ensure that equipment is delivered to the ward in a timely manner it is essential that items with a high priority are stipulated at the time of the request.
All equipment will be delivered in a clean and serviceable condition.
Please note that all equipment is supplied on a short term loan basis and should be returned to the MEL following each patient use.
Returning Equipment – The MEL staff will ensure collections are carried out at least twice daily.
An initial collection will be carried out in the morning and a subsequent collection in the afternoon.
It is essential that all equipment is readily available and easily accessible to our team.

All devices must be socially cleaned following the Trust Decontamination Policy. Pressure Relieving equipment such as Air Therapy Mattress must also be fully deflated, rolled and bagged accordingly, ensuring that the Pump is kept separate from the Mattress and that a fully completed and clearly visible decontamination certificate is included in the mattress sack.
Failures in compliance will be escalated as these failings are contributing towards the unnecessary need for Rental Mattresses.
Appendix 3: Incident reporting to MHRA

The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is an executive of the Department of Health. Their role is to take all reasonable steps to help safeguard public health by working with users, manufacturers and lawmakers to ensure that medical devices meet appropriate standards of safety, quality and performance and that they comply with the relevant Directives of the European Union. One way in which they do this is by investigating reports of adverse incidents involving medical devices.
Where the results of investigations have implications for patients or users, the MHRA issues a Hazard/Safety notice or a Device Alert advising of hazardous products or unsafe procedures.
An adverse incident involving a device should be reported to the MHRA if the incident had led to, or were it to occur again could lead to:
Death.
Life/threatening illness or injury.
Deterioration in health.
Temporary or permanent impairment of a body function or damage to a body
structure.
The necessity for medical or surgical intervention to prevent permanent
impairment of a body function or permanent damage to a body structure.
Unreliable test results leading to inappropriate diagnosis or therapy.
In order to ensure the effectiveness of the distribution and to ensure an audit trail is available for these notices, the following systems have been devised.
Procedure to be followed if a Medical Device is involved in an incident:
The equipment reference number.
Location of the equipment.
Incident report form number.
Name of person reporting the incident.
Contact number of person reporting the incident.
If the incident involves a device that uses consumables such as an infusion device, all single use items must be retained i.e. IV bags, solution sets, syringes etc.
